summary: This is the Office of the Inspector General's report investigating the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York leading up to his death by suicide on August 10, 2019. The report details numerous policy violations, falsification of records, and failures by BOP staff that created an environment where Epstein was left unmonitored and alone in his cell, enabling his suicide. This is the Office of the Inspector General's (OIG) official draft report on the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) care, custody, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It contains eight recommendations for BOP policy changes following Epstein's death, along with the BOP's responses and the OIG's analysis of those responses.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey on federal sex trafficking charges and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: First Hanging Incident
events.description: Epstein found with orange cloth around his neck in his SHU cell; cellmate reported Epstein tried to hang himself. Epstein placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Cellmate Requirement Issued
events.description: Psychology Department emails over 70 staff stating Epstein 'needs to be housed with an appropriate cellmate' upon release from psychological observation.

events.title: Security Camera DVR Failure
events.description: Disk failures in MCC New York's DVR 2 system occur, causing approximately half the institution's cameras (including SHU cameras) to stop recording. Not discovered until August 8.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: Epstein meets with attorneys at MCC New York and signs a new Last Will and Testament. MCC New York officials unaware until after his death.

events.title: Cellmate Transferred, Documents Unsealed
events.description: Epstein's cellmate Inmate 3 transferred out of MCC New York. No new cellmate assigned. Second Circuit unseals ~2000 pages of documents in Ghislaine Maxwell civil litigation, generating extensive media coverage.

events.title: Unmonitored Telephone Call
events.description: Unit Manager allows Epstein to make an unrecorded, unmonitored telephone call on a legal line, purportedly to his mother, but actually to Individual 1.

events.title: Failure to Conduct Counts and Rounds
events.description: SHU staff fail to conduct required 4 p.m. and 10 p.m. inmate counts and 30-minute rounds after approximately 10:40 p.m. Count slips and round sheets are falsified.
personsInvolved: Evening Watch SHU Officer in Charge

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: At approximately 6:30 a.m., Michael Thomas discovers Epstein hanged in his cell with an orange cloth ligature tied to the bunkbed. Epstein pronounced dead at hospital at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Autopsy Results
events.description: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, NYC, performs autopsy and determines cause of death is hanging and manner of death is suicide.

events.title: Charges Dismissed Against Noel and Thomas
events.description: After successfully fulfilling deferred prosecution agreements, charges against Tova Noel and Michael Thomas for falsifying BOP records are dismissed.

keyFacts: Epstein died by suicide via hanging in his SHU cell on August 10, 2019, as determined by the NYC Medical Examiner and FBI investigation.
MCC New York staff failed to assign Epstein a new cellmate on August 9 after his cellmate was transferred, violating a Psychology Department directive issued July 30.
SHU staff, including Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, falsified BOP records to show required inmate counts and 30-minute rounds were conducted when they were not, leaving Epstein unmonitored for hours.
A Unit Manager allowed Epstein to make an unmonitored, unrecorded telephone call on August 9, 2019, in violation of BOP policy.
MCC New York's security camera DVR system had failed on July 29, 2019, and was not repaired until after Epstein's death, limiting recorded video evidence.
The OIG report makes eight specific recommendations to the BOP to improve procedures related to suicide watch, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security, stemming from failures in Epstein's case.

The BOP concurred with all eight recommendations but, according to the OIG's analysis, its response was not fully responsive to Recommendation 2 regarding ensuring high-risk inmates continuously have a cellmate.

The report states that BOP employees failed to ensure Jeffrey Epstein continuously had a cellmate despite Psychology Department personnel determining he needed one, and absent security reasons to the contrary.
The document is an official OIG draft report dated June 22, 2023, and includes the BOP's formal response and the OIG's analysis of that response.
